posts.cooked:
Short version of the question: Is anyone willing to share their PID parameters for x44s as swerve steer motors? We switched from x60s to the x44s and they seem very jittery, even after sysid tuning. The following values give us decent performance, but I am worried they might be under-driving the modules in some cases:

sysid gave kD = 2.5 and kV = 1.25, but the modules never stopped jittering during drive. kS from sysID was also much higher (closer to 2).

Looking at the PID controller outputs in logs (very cool you can see this internal data!), the feedforward and kD outputs are driving very large voltage spikes for relatively small error signals (plots available if interested). Do these smaller values that get rid of most of the jitter make sense?

posts.name: Kyle Reeve
posts.cooked: What’s the gear ratio on your steer? I haven’t touched sysId in a while, but it’s possible sysId is giving you values in terms of motor rotations while your PID is configured with a motorToSensorRatio.
I don’t think this is the case. We supplied sysid with motor voltage and cancoder position and velocity – and used a scaling factor of 1.  I think that is the right approach?

posts.name: Kyle Reeve
posts.cooked: Depends if the rest of your code configures your angle control with cancoder numbers or motor numbers. I notice the kS and kV were both about 1/10th the sysid values, is that close to what your ratio is?

It is … we are using MK4c, which is 12.8:1.  Strange though that the “too large” values we got are actually pretty close to default values in the CTRE generated code (and those default values give similar behavior).

At this point, I am thinking we rerun the generator tool. Maybe something got messed up in there.

posts.name: Kyle Reeve
posts.cooked: Double check if the generated code configures a rotor to sensor ratio

posts.name: Timothy Angert
posts.cooked: Did you get the X44’s working on azimuth, or are they still giving you issues?

We had to tone down the kV, kS, and kD we extracted from SysID, but otherwise they have performed very well through two comps and lots of practice. We often practice 10-15 minutes at a time and have not had any thermal issues under that stress either.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Are you using the PRO license?
Yeah. Everything is pro licensed with drivetrain running on it’s own Canivore based network, and this is running on MK4c modules.
Just manually tune it. Using motion magic voltage or position voltage control modes you should be able to get a very good result in less time than it takes to make these posts
Lol.  I said it’s working well.  That’s what we did.  I was responding to someone who asked if it was working, but thanks for the snarky advice.

suggested_topics.title: YAGSL/Swerve Drive programming help
suggested_topics.excerpt: This is likely a PID issue. Lower your P until it’s stable but still snappy. This likely means your motors aren’t properly inverted, ensure you set the azimuth motors to be inverted. You’re fine to c…

suggested_topics.title: Krackens and sensor suddenly not showing up
suggested_topics.fancy_title: Krackens and sensor suddenly not showing up
suggested_topics.excerpt: We found it after hours and hours. One of our zipties was pulled too tight, it cut into the casing of the wire. After we replaced it everything worked fine again.
